metadata.title: Conversion of bio-oil extracted from Chlorella vulgaris micro algae to biodiesel via modified superparamagnetic nano-biocatalyst

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Renewable Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/renene
Conversion of bio-oil extracted from Chlorella vulgaris micro algae to biodiesel via modified superparamagnetic nano-biocatalyst
Tahereh Nematian a, Zeinab Salehi b, *, Alireza Shakeri a, **
a Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Chemistry, College of Science, University of Tehran, P.O. BOX: 14155-6455, Tehran, Iran b Department of Biotechnology Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 27 September 2018 Received in revised form 16 June 2019 Accepted 8 August 2019 Available online 9 August 2019
Keywords: Lipase immobilization Fe3O4 superparamagnetic Catalyst reusability Biodiesel production Microalgae bio-oil
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: zsalehy@ut.ac.ir (Z. Sale (A. Shakeri).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.08.048 0960-1481/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Rhizopus oryzae lipase (ROL) was loaded on Fe3O4 superparamagnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) with electrostatic attractions and covalent bonding. The nano-biocatalysts were used in biodiesel production process to investigate the effect of enzyme covalent bonding on catalytic performance. For nanobiocatalysts preparation, ROL was loaded on pure MNPs and MNPs functionalized with 3-aminopropyl triethylenesilane (MNP-AP), electrostatically. The enzyme was also bonded to MNPs functionalized with 3-aminopropyl triethylenesilane-glutaraldehyde (MNP-AP-GA), covalently. The hydrolytic activity, kinetic parameters, esterification productivity, and reusability of ROL/MNP, ROL/MNP-AP, and ROL/MNPAP-GA as the four nano-biocatalysts were investigated and compared. The morphology, structure and magnetic characteristics of the MNPs were evaluated using FESEM, FTIR, XRD and VSM. The components of products were analyzed using GC-MS technique. The covalent bonding increased enzyme loading on the support from 36.35 to 51.75 wt %. Transesterification reaction in the presence of ROL/MNP-AP-GA showed the highest conversion (69.8 wt %) among immobilized biocatalysts. Reusability analysis showed that the covalent bonding of enzyme (ROL/MNP-AP-GA) can prevent catalyst wasting, significantly. The conversion after five cycles of reuse for ROL/MNP-AP-GA was 2 times higher than ROL/MNPAP and 3 times higher than ROL/MNP. The covalent bonding of lipase using relatively long chain coupler agents showed to be a reliable method for enhancing enzyme loading and productivity.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Growing dependence on petroleum as the main source of energy and chemical precursors has faced humankind with different social and environmental problems. Carbon release into the atmosphere especially in the forms of CO2 and CO, has increased air pollution and subsequently causes global warming. Investment in supplement renewable energy resources is a practical solution for rate decreasing of CO2 emission into the environment. Biodiesel is an attractive renewable transportation fuel because it is biodegradable and non-toxic. Furthermore, less hazardous gases emission due to higher oxygen content as well as zero sulfur and aromatic substances, make it a prominent alternative for fossil fuels [1e3].
hi), alireza.shakeri@ut.ac.ir
Fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) are well-known type of biodiesel produced from transesterification of vegetable oils and animal fats with short-chain alcohols. Microalgae because of high photosynthesis and oil production efficiency, growing ability in non-fresh water and low land area requirement is an affordable feedstock for biodiesel production compared with edible sources [4e7]. Among numerous algal species, Chlorella vulgaris, due to lipid rich content and easy cultivation has great potential for converting to biodiesel [8]. Biomass and lipid productivity of Chlorella vulgaris have been reported up to 0.16 g (dry weight).L 1.day 1 and 34mg L 1.day 1, respectively [9]. Transesterification reaction has been performed using low molecular weight alcohols in the presence of acid, alkali, and enzymatic catalysts. The catalysts are also classified to homogenous or heterogeneous [10]. Recently, researchers has become more interested in enzymatic transesterification of oils and fats. Easy isolation and purification of produced fuel, gentle reactionmedium and no by-product and soap production make this process a promising method for biodiesel production [11].
Lipase (EC 3.1.1.3) is known to be an effective biocatalyst for
reactions such as esterification, transesterification, alcoholysis, and aminolysis. It has been demonstrated that lipase has excellent catalytic activity, specificity, and stability in transesterification of triglycerides. However, relatively high cost of enzyme is the most important limitation for using it as catalyst. Immobilization of enzyme can decrease the cost of enzymatic processes and improve stability and reusability of the catalyst [12e15]. Physical adsorption, covalent binding, cross-linking, and encapsulation are methods for immobilization of lipase on various solid supports [16e20]. Covalent bonding is one of the most widely used method for irreversible enzyme immobilization that enhances thermal stability and efficiency as well as prevents enzyme leaching [21].
A wide range of organic and inorganic materials such as silica, chitosan, polymeric resins and Fe3O4 have been used as support for enzymes immobilization [22e25]. Covalent bonding of enzymes to Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles has been carried out to prepare a magnetic nano-biocatalyst with low toxicity, costeffective design and high surface area [26]. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and 3-aminopropyl triethylenesilane (AP) have been used for modification of Fe3O4 and subsequently enzyme immobilization. Both of Fe3O4@TEOS and Fe3O4-AP can tolerate higher enzyme loading and cause easier biocatalyst separation in magnetic field compared with bare Fe3O4 [27]. Hydrolytic activity tests of Candida rugosa lipase immobilized on Fe3O4/polystyrene-polyacrylic acid functionalized with carboxyl groups has been studied and results showed an improvement in physical stability of biocatalyst [28]. In order to increase the stability of biocatalyst and reduction of steric hindrance, epoxy, glutaraldehyde, glyoxalactivated supports have also been investigated [29e31]. The effects of 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-carbodiimide (EDC) and glutaraldehyde have been compared in trypsin immobilized on Carboxymethyl chitosan (CM-CTS)-functionalized magnetic nanoparticles (Fe3O4@CM-CTS). Results indicate that attachment of glutaraldehyde (GA) improve stability and reusability of biocatalysts [32].
In this study, Chlorella vulgaris microalgae was cultivated in a modified BG11 medium for lipid production enhancement. Superparamagnetic nanoparticles of iron oxide (MNP) were synthesized via chemical co-precipitation method. Rhizopus oryzae lipase (ROL) was immobilized onMNPwith covalent and non-covalent linkages. Covalent bonds between MNP and ROL were created using both 3- aminopropyl triethylenesilane (AP) and glutaraldehyde (GA). The activity, productivity, and reusability of the nano-biocatalysts for biodiesel production from microalgae oil were investigated to find the covalent bonding effect on catalytic performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Rhizopus oryzae lipase (light brown powder, 30,000 U/g) was purchased from SigmaeAldrich. Reagents for characterization of ROL, para-nitrophenyl palmitate (p-NPP), isopropyl alcohol (99.7%), bovine serum albumin (BSA), Coomassie Brilliant Blue G-250, Triton X-100 and Arabic gum were purchased from Merck. For nano-biocatalyst preparation, iron (II) sulfate tetrahydrate (FeSO4.4H2O, 99.7%), iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O, 99.0%), ammonia (NH4OH, 25wt %), absolute ethanol, 3-aminopropyl triethoxysilane (AP) and glutaraldehyde (GA) were purchased from Merck. Components of BG-11 medium (Blue-Green medium) in which the microalgae Chlorella vulgaris CCAP (211/19) was preserved and grown, were obtained from Merck. All organic solvents and other chemicals purchased from Merck were of analytical grade.

sections.heading: 2.2. Microalgae cultivation and lipid extraction
sections.text:
Chlorella vulgaris CCAP (211/19)was cultivated in BG-11 medium using glassy tubular photo-bioreactor under continuous 4 Klux cool-white LED. The medium and flasks were sterilized in an autoclave vessel for 20min at 121 C to prevent any contamination during early stages of growth. Nitrate starvationwas employed as a most widely used strategy to improve lipid content in autotrophic cultivation [33].
The culture medium during the first 6 days was composed of modified BG11. For the second 6 days, microalgae cultivation mixture was diluted by half with free nitrate BG11 solutionwith the aim of increasing biomass lipid content. After 12 days cultivation, the microalgae was harvested using centrifugation (40min, 4000 rpm) and washed twice with deionized water. The sulphophospho-vanillin (SPV) method was used for determination of the total lipid content [34]. The maximum lipid content were 35wt %. Lipid extraction from dry biomass was carried out via liquideliquid extraction using ethanol, water, and hexane as solvents. Dry biomass (10 g) was mixed with 30mL ethanol (96% v/v) in a 250mL single-neck round bottom flask equipped with reflux condenser at 60 C for 12 h. Water and hexane were added to the solution to achieve ethanol: water: hexane volume ratio of 1:0.6:0.3 [35]. Nonpolar and polar lipids were concentrated in upper (hexane) and lower (water-ethanol) layers, respectively. The upper layer was carefully collected and evaporated in a rotary evaporator to obtain crude lipid and distilled hexane.

sections.heading: 2.3. Superparamagnetic nanoparticles preparation
sections.text: MNP were synthesized via co-precipitation method. The aqueous solution of FeCl3.6H2O and FeSO4.4H2O with 2:1M ratio was prepared in 90 cm3 deionized water and moderately stirred under nitrogen atmosphere at 85 C. After 15min, 6 cm3 of 25% ammonia was added to the solution for pH adjustment around 9. The reaction mixture was maintained for 1 h. The black sediment (MNP) was collected using an external magnetic field and washed several times with deionized water. For functionalization of magnetite by 3eamino propyl triethoxysilane (MNP-AP), 0.05 g MNP was dispersed in 4.6 cm3 ethanol and sonicated under 70 kHz frequency. Afterward, 0.100 cm3 acetic acid and 0.100 cm3 AP were added to the mixture and shaken for 5 h at room temperature. The product was separated using external magnetic field and washed with deionized water. To functionalize MNP by both AP and GA (MNP-AP-GA), 0.040 cm3 GAwas added to the synthesized MNP-AP and shaken for 2 h at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.4. Nanoparticle characterization
sections.text: Surface morphology of MNPs and their size were detected by TESCAN MIRA3 XMU field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). Element distribution was detected from the energy dispersive spectrometer analysis (EDS-Element mapping). X-ray diffraction (XRD), using a Philips Analytical X-ray diffractometer (XPert MPD) with monochromatized Cu/KÂ radiation, was used for phase detection. The FT-IR spectra for MNP, MNP-AP, MNP-AP-GA, ROL and ROL/MNP-AP-GA were recorded in range of 4000 cm 1 to 400 cm 1 using KBr matrix using Bruker Tensor 27 Fouriertransform infrared spectroscopy. Magnetic properties of bare MNP and functionalized ones were measured with a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM, Meghnatis Daghigh Kavir Co., Iran) at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.5. Enzyme immobilization
sections.text: To immobilize Rhizopus oryzae lipase, 5mg of each MNP, MNPAP and MNP-AP-GA was suspended in 1 cm3 of 100mM phosphate buffer at pH¼ 7.5 andmixedwith 0.300 cm3 enzyme solution (150mg cm 3). The immobilization process was carried out at 4 C for 17 h in incubator shaker at a stirring speed of 120 rpm. After the reaction, Samples were washed five times with buffer solution. Protein content loading was measured with the Bradford's method using BSA as a standard. The amount of immobilized enzyme was calculated by difference in the initial and not bounded ROL concentration.

sections.heading: 2.6. Nano-biocatalyst hydrolytic activity
sections.text: Hydrolytic activity of free and immobilize ROL was evaluated through hydrolysis of p-NPP as substrate. Solution A (16.5mM pNPP solution in isopropanol) and solution B (0.01 g Arabic gum and 0.04 cm3 of Triton X-100 in 10 cm3 PBS; 100mM, pH 7.5) were prepared. Substrate solution is a mixture of 1:9 vol ratio of solution A to solution B. Then 8.6mg of ROL was added to 1 cm3 of substrate solution and release of p-nitrophenol was measured using UVevisible spectrophotometry (Varian Cary 100 Spectrophotometer) at 410 nm. One unit of enzyme (1U) was defined as amount of biocatalyst that released 1 mmol of p-nitro phenol per minute under the assay condition. All experiments for nano-biocatalyst activity and kinetic parameters were repeated for three times and results averageswere reported. To evaluate enzyme activity and the kinetic parameters differences between the study groups, statistical analysis was done. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and least significant difference (LSD) post-hoc tests were used for statistical analysis. Pvalues less than 0.05 were considered as significant.

sections.heading: 2.7. Kinetic parameters
sections.text: Determination of Vmax and Km values for p-nitrophenyl palmitate hydrolysis were carried out by using Michaelis-Menten and Lineweaver-Burk plots for all biocatalysts [36]. Lineweaver-Burk plots was created by measuring initial velocity (V0) at different concentration from 0.1 to 2mM of substrate (S) in the assay mixtures under the optimum experimental conditions.

sections.heading: 2.8. Biodiesel production
sections.text:
Extracted microalgae lipid was converted to fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) in an enzymatic methanolysis reaction. The reaction was performed at 45 C for 24 h. The 8.6mg of free and immobilized ROL was added to 0.5 cm3 extracted lipid dissolved in n-Hexane (5mg cm 3) and 0.15 cm3 of methanol was added in three time steps of reaction 0, 8 and 12 h to avoid ROL deactivation. High methanol concentrations are generally toxic to ROL and caused decreasing its enzyme activity and stability [37].
Enzymatic transesterification was carried out at 60, 55, 50, 45, and 40 C. No FAMEs were detected at 60 and 40 C that can be related to enzyme deactivation at higher temperatures and very low reaction rate at lower temperatures, respectively. So, the minimum temperature was selected, because lower temperatures are preferred for industrial applications. The pH¼ 7.5 was selected for the reaction medium, because the pH range for ROL activity is 7e8 and many researches find the best activity of ROL in pH¼ 7.5 [38]. Afterward, nano-biocatalyst was collected using external magnetic field and liquid phase was separated and centrifuged to appear two phase media. Upper phase was analyzed with GC-MS technique for detection and calculation of products. Biocatalysts were reused in reactions with mentioned condition. For reusing
experiments, each nano-biocatalyst was washed with hexane for removing the adhered algae oil before using in the next step. Reaction conversion was defined as the weight percentage of initial algae oil that was converted to FAMEs.

sections.heading: 2.9. Product analysis
sections.text: Compositions of products were analyzed using a GC-MS system of HP Agilent Technology 6890 Network GC System with column HP-5MS (Length: 30m, internal diameter: 0.25mm, Film thickness: 0.25 mm and Material: Fused silica) and MS (5973 Network Mass Selective Detector). The carrier gas was helium (99.999% purity). The injection port temperature was set at 250 C. The oven temperature program was initial temperature of 60 C, initial time of 2min, temperature rate of 10 C.min 1 up to 200 C and 5 C.min 1 to 240 C and finally, hold at 240 C for 7min. The ion source temperature for mass spectrometer was 250 C, and the ionization mode was electron impact with electron energy of 70 eV. Heptadecanoic acid methyl ester (C18:0) was used as internal standard.

sections.heading: 3.1. Nanoparticles characterization
sections.text:
Phase detection for synthesized supports was performed by XRD technique (Fig. 1). Six characteristic peaks at 2q of 30.0 , 35.4 , 43.1 , 53.5 , 57.0 , and 62.6 confirmed the formation of crystalline structure of MNP that was agreed with standard MNP XRD spectrum [39]. As shown in the XRD pattern, the diffraction peaks for MNP-AP, MNP-AP-GA and also ROL/MNP-AP-GA are similar to bare MNP which means that crystal structure of MNP was well maintained after functionalization and immobilization process.
The FT-IR technique was used for MNP, MNP-AP, MNP-AP-GA, ROL, and ROL/MNP-AP-GA characterization and also to confirm the immobilization of ROL on MNP-AP-GA (Fig. 2). Peaks at 567 cm 1 is related to the FeeO bond. For bare MNP (Fig. 2a), broad peak at 3400 cm 1 belongs to OeH bond. The first functionalization step of MNPwith AP (Fig. 2b) was identified by peaks appeared at 1125 and 2923 cm 1 related to SieO and CeH bonds, respectively [40]. The ethoxy group leaves the AP structure with the attack of hydroxyl oxygen atoms to the Si. It causes the covalent grafting of Si to MNP surface. In MNP-AP-GA FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 2c), a peak that
observed at 1613 cm 1 can be related to N¼C covalent bond formation of glutaraldehyde to AP functional groups [41]. With grafting of GA to MNP-AP, the CeH bonds on the support increases. Therefore, the peak related to CeH at 1200 cm 1 become more visible compare with MNP-AP spectrum. In the FTIR spectra of ROL
(Fig. 2d), amide I and amide II bands are two major bands of the protein which were exhibited at 1610 cm 1 and 1480 cm 1, respectively. The characteristic peak at 1610 cm 1 is commonly referred to C¼O stretching vibration in amid І, and 1480 cm 1 is essentially associated with the NeH bending and CeN stretching vibrations in amide II [42]. The FTIR spectrum of ROL/MNP-AP-GA (Fig. 2e) shows the characteristic absorption bands of both magnetite and enzyme and confirmed that the ROL were successfully immobilized on MNP-AP-GA support.
FESEM technique was carried out to explore synthesized MNP particles and ROL/MNP-AP-GA morphology and size distribution (Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 3A, MNP particle size was in range of 20e30 nm and the spherical shape was obvious on FESEM micrographs. Fig. 3B, C, and 3D illustrates FESEM and the EDS elemental mapping of ROL/MNP-AP-GA.
The brighter fine zones that are clearly visible on the surface of particles in FESEM micrograph (Fig. 3c), can be related to ROL immobilization on MNP-AP-GA [43]. Good distribution of elements was concluded from EDS-Element mapping. Four main elements Fe, C, O, and N (Fig. 3d) were observed and attributed to ROL/MNPAP-GA nanobiocatalysts [44].
The magnetic properties of all samples were analyzed by vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) analysis. Fig. 4 shows VSM
d D) The EDS elemental mapping image of ROL/MNP-AP-GA.
graphs for (a) MNP, (b) MNP-AP and (c) MNP-AP-GA. The magnetic response of MNP, MNP-AP, and MNP-AP-GA were 63, 56, and 50 emu.g 1, respectively. Decreasing in magnetic response is related to AP and GA grafting onMNP. Addition of nonmagnetic component to magnetic one caused a depletion in magnetic properties of MNP. However, the typical VSM graphs of MNP and modified MNPs demonstrated that all produced MNPs were superparamagnetic [45].

sections.heading: 3.2. Nano- biocatalysts assay and activity
sections.text:
Activity of immobilized ROL on supports were evaluated and results were reported in Fig. 5. Assay of enzyme powder was revealed 46wt percent using Bradford's method. The percentage of
enzyme loading was varied from 36.35 to 51.74wt %. Themaximum ROL loading of 51.74wt % was recorded for MNP-AP-GA nano-biocatalyst. Fig. 6 is a graphical showing of the reaction for modifying the MNP with AP and GA groups and immobilizing ROL on the spheres. Grafting of AP and GA to MNP surface creates a wider spherical area for enzyme attachment. Wider space can decrease steric hindrance as well as facilitate accessibility of substrate to enzyme active sites. The reaction kinetics for free and immobilized enzymes was studied by measuring the kinetic parameters (Km and Vmax) for the hydrolytic activity. Km is the substrate concentration that is required for the reaction to occur at 0.5 Vmax. An obvious reduction for Km value was occurred with ROL immobilization on magnetic nanoparticles. Attachment of glutaraldehyde increased MNP surface hydrophilicity and caused a higher affinity of substrate for immobilized ROL [46].
As shown in Fig. 5, there was a diminution after immobilization in Vmax due to substrate diffusion limit and conformational changes of enzyme after immobilization. It has been reported that the Vmax value undergoes a reduction after immobilization of lipase on other supports such as different magnetic nanoparticles, cellulose substrate, and chitosan [47e49]. However, after functionalization, because of wider space, accessibility to enzyme active sites was increased and consequently Vmax values were increased.
Enzyme hydrolytic activity decreased after immobilization on support. It can be related to partial conformational change of enzyme during immobilization [50e52].

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of solvent ratio on biodiesel conversion
sections.text:
Hexane is a non-polar solvent that can trap the water and create micro-aqueous layer surrounding lipase. The fact causes maintaining the conformation of ROL and preserving its catalytic activity but higher concentration of hexane can reduce the interaction between algae oil and lipase [53]. Therefore, it is necessary to
rs for free and immobilized ROL.
optimize hexane to lipid ratio in reactions such as transesterification. Solutions with different concentrations of lipid in hexane, 1, 3, 6, 9, 12 cm3 solvent per gram of lipid, were prepared and used as reaction feed to find the optimum ratio of hexane to lipid on biodiesel conversion (Fig. 7). Maximum biodiesel
production was obtained in a medium with 9mL solvent.g 1 lipid. The solutions with lower hexane to lipid ratios have higher concentrations and viscosities. The fact causes higher mass transfer resistance and can be a reason for lower FAMEs conversion in the concentrated media. Increasing hexane to lipid ratio from 1 to 9 showed increasing in conversion. It can be related to decreasing mass transfer resistance by using more solvent. However, the higher amounts of solvent dilute the reaction medium and as a result, the rate of the reaction {{}}decreases due to the low substrate concentration.

sections.heading: 3.4. Biodiesel analysis
sections.text:
Products were analyzed using GC-MS to find their natures and amounts. The most crowded chromatogram of the products was presented in Fig. 8. Methyl palmitate, Methyl stearate, Methyl (7E,10E)-7,10-hexadecadienoate and Methyl (9Z,12Z,15Z)-9,12,15octadecatrienoate were FAMEs that GC-MS detected in the productmixture. The FAMEs and other compoundswhichwere detected in the product mixture are shown in Table 1. The product mixture is composed of FAMEs, alcohols, hydrocarbons, and aromatics. Although the produced biodiesel should undergo an upgrading step
before use as engine fuel, all these materials have the combustion ability and can be present in the final mixture of biodiesel [54]. Fig. 9 shows algae oil conversion to biodiesel in the presence of free ROL and ROL supported on MNP, MNP-AP, and MNP-AP-GA. After enzyme immobilization a slight general decrease of activity was accrued that can be due to enzyme conformational changes. However, because of higher stability and longer lifetime, immobilized enzymes have been used for biodiesel production. The lifetime of the free enzyme in the reaction media is typically a few hours to a couple of days and varies by changing in pH and temperature. Even though the activity of free enzyme is higher than the immobilized one [55].
ROL/MNP showed the lowest conversion (54.14%). Since physical adsorption does not significantly change conformational of the enzyme, hydrolysis activity of ROL/MNP was higher than other nano-biocatalysts but had the lowest conversion in transesterification reaction. Compared with hydrolysis reaction,
microalgae oil enzymatic transesterification requires harsh conditions such as higher reactant and product concentrations, higher temperatures and longer time reactions [56]. The conditions cause moremolecular contacts and interactions. Since physical bonding is generally too weak to keep the enzyme fixed on support, more leakage of ROL from bare MNP may occur; subsequently FAME conversion would reduce. The none-functionalized MNP as a lipase support for biodiesel production from soybean oil was previously reported. This catalyst could convert the 44% of oil to FAMEs [57].
As shown in Fig. 9 process conversion increased in the present of ROL/MNP-AP. Amine groups of AP provide a larger polar area around support surface. It causes dipolar interaction between the support and enzyme and simultaneously less steric hindrance compare with ROL/MNP. Therefore, the fact leaded biocatalyst to higher enzyme loadings and productivity. ROL/MNP-AP-GA showed the highest conversion which was comparable with free ROL. The aldehyde groups in glutaraldehyde react with amine groups of ROL
and create covalent double bond C¼N. The bonds promote ROL rigidity and avoid enzyme leaching and keep it active for longer times.
In other recent researches about biodiesel production in the presence of paramagnetic nanobiocatalysts, the hydrolysis activity and biodiesel conversion of catalysts have been investigated. The palm oil has been used as feedstock for biodiesel production in the presence of lipase immobilized on functionalized MNP with EDC (1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide), EDC-GA, APEDC/NHS (AP-EDC/N-hydroxysuccinimide), AP-EDC/NHS-GA. Results showed the hydrolysis activity from 1.3 to 32 and the biodiesel conversion from 10.28 to 85.04%, and AP-EDC/NHS-GAwas the best reagent for MNP functionalization [58]. A biodiesel conversion of 71% also has been reported for transesterification of soybean oil in the presence of covalent bonded lipase to MNP. The MNP has been coated with SiO2 and functionalized with AP-GA as well as MPTMS (3-Mercaptopropyltrimethoxysilane)-GA before lipase immobilization [59].
The reusability of nano-biocatalystswas investigated and results was shown in Fig.10. The 57.2% of FAME conversionwasmaintained after five cycles of reusing reactions in present of ROL/MNP-AP-GA even if the reusability is poor. This is the best reusing performance among three nano-biocatalysts. This fact confirmed the positive effect of covalent linkages formation between the support and ROL
on conformational stability of ROL immobilized on MNP-AP-GA over a multi-cycle reuse compared to others.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
FAMEs as a type of biodiesel were produced from Chlorella vulgaris lipid in presence of free and immobilized Rhizopus oryzae lipase. Compared with BG-11 medium, higher lipid content (35wt %) from Chlorella vulgaris algae cultivated in modified BG-11 mediumwas obtained. Based upon an idea that enzyme attachment to an appropriate support may help biocatalyst being more stable and reusable, ROL was immobilized on superparamagnetic nanoparticle (MNP). ROL immobilized on MNP and functionalized MNP showed enabling rapid separation under external magnetic fields and subsequent multiple recycling potential. Covalent bonds and dipolar attractions of ROL to MNPwas carried out via AP and AP-GA as coupling interfaces. Functionalization MNP with AP and AP-GA caused obvious increasing in enzyme loading but enzyme hydrolytic activity was reduced. It can be related to protein accumulation and low chance of the substrate to access the enzyme active sites in short-time hydrolysis reaction. However, functionalization of MNP by AP-GA caused that the interaction between the support and lipase became stronger because of covalent bond creation. It made biocatalyst more stable and resistant in microalgae oil transesterification that performed in longer time reactions. Therefore, the highest biodiesel conversion and the best reusability among other immobilized biocatalysts were shown by ROL/MNP-AP-GA, even if its reusability is poor.
Conflicts of interest
The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.

referenceMentions.context: Among numerous algal species, Chlorella vulgaris, due to lipid rich content and easy cultivation has great potential for converting to biodiesel [8].
The catalysts are also classified to homogenous or heterogeneous [10].
Easy isolation and purification of produced fuel, gentle reactionmedium and no by-product and soap production make this process a promising method for biodiesel production [11].
Covalent bonding is one of the most widely used method for irreversible enzyme immobilization that enhances thermal stability and efficiency as well as prevents enzyme leaching [21].
Covalent bonding of enzymes to Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles has been carried out to prepare a magnetic nano-biocatalyst with low toxicity, costeffective design and high surface area [26].
Both of Fe3O4@TEOS and Fe3O4-AP can tolerate higher enzyme loading and cause easier biocatalyst separation in magnetic field compared with bare Fe3O4 [27].

Hydrolytic activity tests of Candida rugosa lipase immobilized on Fe3O4/polystyrene-polyacrylic acid functionalized with carboxyl groups has been studied and results showed an improvement in physical stability of biocatalyst [28].
Results indicate that attachment of glutaraldehyde (GA) improve stability and reusability of biocatalysts [32].
Nitrate starvationwas employed as a most widely used strategy to improve lipid content in autotrophic cultivation [33].
The sulphophospho-vanillin (SPV) method was used for determination of the total lipid content [34].

Attachment of glutaraldehyde increased MNP surface hydrophilicity and caused a higher affinity of substrate for immobilized ROL [46].

metadata.abstractText: Rhizopus oryzae lipase (ROL) was loaded on Fe3O4 superparamagnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) with electrostatic attractions and covalent bonding. The nano-biocatalysts were used in biodiesel production process to investigate the effect of enzyme covalent bonding on catalytic performance. For nanobiocatalysts preparation, ROL was loaded on pure MNPs and MNPs functionalized with 3-aminopropyl triethylenesilane (MNP-AP), electrostatically. The enzyme was also bonded to MNPs functionalized with 3-aminopropyl triethylenesilane-glutaraldehyde (MNP-AP-GA), covalently. The hydrolytic activity, kinetic parameters, esterification productivity, and reusability of ROL/MNP, ROL/MNP-AP, and ROL/MNPAP-GA as the four nano-biocatalysts were investigated and compared. The morphology, structure and magnetic characteristics of the MNPs were evaluated using FESEM, FTIR, XRD and VSM. The components of products were analyzed using GC-MS technique. The covalent bonding increased enzyme loading on the support from 36.35 to 51.75 wt %. Transesterification reaction in the presence of ROL/MNP-AP-GA showed the highest conversion (69.8 wt %) among immobilized biocatalysts. Reusability analysis showed that the covalent bonding of enzyme (ROL/MNP-AP-GA) can prevent catalyst wasting, significantly. The conversion after five cycles of reuse for ROL/MNP-AP-GA was 2 times higher than ROL/MNPAP and 3 times higher than ROL/MNP. The covalent bonding of lipase using relatively long chain coupler agents showed to be a reliable method for enhancing enzyme loading and productivity. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
